Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC: Phase 2 - UMaine Membership in IUCRC Center for Advanced Forestry Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
In Phase II operation, the University of Maine Site of the I/UCRC for Advanced Forestry Systems (CAFS) intends to focus on optimizing the silvicultural and genetic systems needed to produce high quality, raw materials thereby contributing to the cooperative research of the center and making significant progress in increasing forest productivity through forest genetics, site manipulation, and better growth & yield modeling. Many of the problems and opportunities facing the management of forests today bridge disciplinary and regional boundaries. To achieve the technological advances needed for new 21st century challenges, existing university/industry cooperatives must approach research questions at multiple spatial (including the molecular, cellular, individual-tree, stand, forest, and ecosystem levels) and temporal scales.

Research conducted by the University of Maine site of CAFS increases the competitiveness of forest products industries and forest landowners. Industrial members benefit by becoming knowledgeable about a wider range of technological capabilities and technology transfer between CAFS scientists and member personnel fosters rapid implementation of new technologies. Students trained via CAFS research are unique in the forestry sciences because of their applied problem-solving skills using interdisciplinary techniques across multiple scales. Aggressive recruiting for graduate students among under-represented groups will continue to be conducted, increasing the diversity of the workforce for both academia and industry in this traditionally diversity-deficient discipline. Opportunities will continue to be sought to involve undergraduate students in CAFS research activities, exposing them to the excitement of forest science and encouraging them to pursue graduate education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported the University of Maine’s participation in Phase II of the NSF Industry-University Cooperative Research Center for Advanced Forestry Systems (CAFS). The collaborative research focuses on optimizing the silvicultural and genetic systems needed to produce high quality, raw materials to meet the economic demands of the nation’s forest products industry in the 21st century.

 

Our specific objectives were: i) develop growth and yield predictions for diverse genotypes and silvicultural practices; ii) extend the Acadian Variant of the Forest Vegetation Simulator (FVS-ACD) to managed stands in the Northeast US, and iii) enhance our understanding about individual tree responses to commercial thinning. We also addressed emerging issues including the increase of endemic invasive tree species (i.e., American beech and red maple), effects of widespread partial harvesting, and preparation for the next spruce budworm outbreak. All projects were completed as outlined in our Phase 2 proposal.

 

Intellectual merit: Models were developed or refined for i) estimating site maximum carrying capacity at a regional scale; ii) including tree species as a random effect to analyze growth and yield in mixed-species forests; iii) estimating individual tree diameter increment and survival; iv) predicting the impact of early successional dynamics and management activities on growth and yield of forest stands; v) simulating the impact of spruce budworm outbreaks and prediction of individual tree defoliation; and vi) predicting harvest probability of occurrence and intensity.

 

Five peer-reviewed publications were published and a sixth has been accepted for publication. An IUCRC Phase III award will support continuation of research in three primary focal areas (forest management, forest genetics, and decision-support tools) and the additional of remote sensing as a fourth focal area.

 

Broader impact: This project strengthened links between universities and the forest products industry in Maine by supporting research driven by interactions with cooperators and their needs, with a focus on naturally regenerated, managed forest. This project supported the refinement of a decision-support tool that is widely used in the region to help land managers understand, predict, and evaluate alternative strategies for managing their forests. Cooperators included 17 industrial firms, one government agency and one nonprofit organization.

 

We provided significant training opportunities for 14 undergraduate students, 16 master’s students, three Ph.D students, and 2 post-doctoral researchers. This has ranged from learning basic field skills and acquiring technical skills like data management and analysis to professional opportunities such as participation in regional and national meetings. Two post-docs have taken permanent science positions, nine graduates have been hired by industry firms and two have been hired by government members of the consortium.
